official-title.#text:
To direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services, acting through the Director of the Centers
			 for Disease Control and Prevention, to establish a surveillance system
			 regarding traumatic brain injury, and for other purposes.

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: National Traumatic Brain Injury Research and Treatment Improvement Act of 2014
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: National Traumatic Brain Injury Research and Treatment Improvement Act of 2014

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the
The

State data and monitoring systems provide reliable data on injury causes and risk factors, identify
			 trends in the incidence of traumatic brain injury, enable the development
			 of cause-specific prevention strategies focused on populations at greatest
			 risk, and monitor the effectiveness of such strategies.

Since 1995, when the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention published Guidelines for
			 Surveillance of Central Nervous System Injury, additional causes of
			 traumatic brain injury have emerged: military-related traumatic brain
			 injuries; sports-related concussions; traffic injuries resulting from
			 texting while driving; and increasing numbers of falls-related traumatic
			 brain injuries among older adults.

In their 2013 report, Sports-Related Concussions in Youth: Improving the Science, Changing the
			 Culture, the Institute on Medicine and the National Research Council noted
			 that there is currently a lack
			 of data to accurately estimate the incidence of sports-related concussions
			 across a variety of sports and for youth across the pediatric age
			 spectrum. The report recommended that the Centers for Disease Control and
			 Prevention establish and oversee a national surveillance system to
			 accurately determine the incidence of sports-related concussions,
			 including those in youth ages 5 to 21, taking into account Federal efforts
			 to collect information on traumatic brain injury.

Traumatic brain injury is a substantial public health problem among older persons. As the
			 population of older persons continues to grow in the United States, the
			 need to design and implement proven and cost-effective prevention measures
			 that focus on the leading causes of traumatic brain injury becomes more
			 urgent.

In order to implement this Act, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention needs to collaborate
			 with Federal agencies reporting military-related traumatic brain injuries,
			 school systems reporting traumatic brain injuries, Medicaid and other
			 Federal programs, and State agencies.

header.#text: Establishing requirements to improve the research and treatment of traumatic brain injury

quote.#text: National Traumatic Brain Injury Surveillance System

text.#text:
establish a statistically sound, scientifically credible, integrated surveillance system regarding
			 traumatic brain injury, to be known as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall ensure that the National Traumatic Brain Injury Surveillance System is designed
			 in a manner that facilitates further research on brain injury.

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: National Traumatic Brain Injury Research and Treatment Improvement Act of 2014/s:3/ss:a

text.#text: In carrying out

to the extent practicable, shall provide for the collection and storage of other available
			 information (excluding personally identifiable information) on traumatic
			 brain injury, such as information concerning demographics and other
			 information associated with the incidence of a traumatic brain injury,
			 such as—
age;
race and ethnicity;
sex;
geographic location;
history of head injury (including injury type and the approximate date of injury);

pre-existing conditions, such as learning disabilities and attention deficit hyperactivity
			 disorder; and
co-occurring issues, such as substance abuse or post-traumatic stress disorder;

to the extent practicable, shall provide for the collection and storage of information relevant to
			 analysis on traumatic brain injury, such as information concerning—
impact location on the body and nature of the impact;
qualifications of personnel making the traumatic brain injury diagnosis;
assessment tool used to make the diagnosis;
signs and symptoms consistent with a head injury;
sport or activity and the level of competition (if a sports-related activity);
use of protective equipment and impact monitoring devices; and
severity of the traumatic brain injury; and

medical facilities of the
behavioral health centers.

shall ensure that privacy and security protections applicable to the National
			 Traumatic Brain Injury Surveillance System are at least as stringent as
			 the privacy and security protections under HIPAA privacy and security law,
			 including nondisclosure of personally identifiable information.

term.#tail:
means information which can be used to distinguish or trace an individual’s identity (such as
			 their name, social security number, or biometric records) either alone or
			 when combined with other personal or identifying information which is
			 linked or linkable to a specific individual (such as date of birth, place
			 of birth, and mother’s maiden name).

text.#text: The term

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Secretary of Health and Human Services

text.#text: The term

term.#tail:
means the ongoing, systematic collection, analysis, interpretation, and dissemination of data
			 (other than personally identifiable information) regarding a
			 health-related event for use in public health action to reduce morbidity
			 and mortality and to improve health.

text.#text: The term

term.#tail:
means an injury to the head arising from blunt or penetrating trauma or from acceleration or
			 deceleration forces associated with one or more of the following:
			 decreased level of consciousness, amnesia, objective neurologic or
			 neuropsychological abnormalities, skull fractures, diagnosed intracranial
			 lesions, or head injury listed as a cause of death in the death
			 certificate.
